Hierarchically structured polymer fibers encompassing 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D structures with at least one dimension nano- to micro-meters in size have recently received an increasing amount of attention due to their vast potential in such applications as sensing, medicine, energy storage. This review summarizes advancements in the last ten years in the design and fabrication of hierarchically structured polymer fibers via electrospinning technologies, including a diversity of electrospinning devices and electrospinning parameters using various polymers. These well-defined, multilevel structures enable the fibers to be
eywords: ierarchical structures iomaterials rug delivery issue engineering lectrospinning
used more effectively in applications in the biomedical field, such as drug delivery, tissue engineering, and diagnostics. This review can provide a better understanding of the relationships between the structure and functionality of polymer fibers for further biomedical applications.

. Introduction
Hierarchically complex structures are observed in many iological systems [1–4], and these structures impart diverse funcionalities to organisms, such as nanoscale viruses, microscale cells, nd macroscale tissues. For example, bone tissues possess an unusal ombination of remarkable strength and toughness, attributed to heir precisely organized hierarchical structures: nanometer-sized ydroxyapatite crystals periodically deposit within the gap zones f collagen fibrils, leading to excellent nanomechanical heteroeneities and enabling a mechanism for high energy dissipation and esistance to fracture [3]. So far, various hierarchical structures (e.g., ero dimensional (0-D) particles [5,6], one dimensional (1-D) fibers 7], two dimensional (2-D) substrates [8–10] and three dimenional (3-D) scaffolds [11]) have been developed for biomedicine nd other applications. Among these structures, hierarchically tructured fibers with diameters ranging from nano- to microeters as well as wires and tubes, can be used as building blocks o assemble 1-D to 3-D structures. These hierarchically strucured fibers represent an important category and have attracted
great deal of attention in the biomedical field and other scientific esearch fields (e.g., electronics [12], optics [13], sensors [13,14], atalysis [15],energy storage [16–18], oil/water separation [19], nd air filtration [20,21]), because they possess a larger specific rea and additional heterogeneous interfaces, which may play an mportant role in enhancing the nanosize effect [22]. Numerous pproaches have been developed for fabricating 1-D fibers in recent ears [23–27]. However, very few review articles have specifically eported the progress in electrospun polymeric fibers with a hierrchical structure from 1-D to 2-D to 3-D and with fiber diameters rom nano- to mico-meters.
In this review, we provide a comprehensive overview of recent esearch regarding the design and fabrication of electrospun hierrchically structured polymer fibers for biomedical applications ncluding drug delivery, tissue engineering, diagnostics and others, s shown in Fig. 1. Electrospinning is a facile and multifunc-
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 107
tional technique used to produce ultrafine, continuous fibers with controllable diameters in the range of nanometers to micrometers, from either organic or inorganic materials [28–31]. These electrospun fibers, possessing a large specific surface area, a high aspect ratio, a high porosity, a controllable small pore size and the ability to resemble an extracellular matrix’s architecture, are widely used in a variety of fields, including filtration and adsorption, sensing, self-cleaning, catalysis, food engineering, nanofiber-reinforced composites, optoelectronics, energy storage and biomedical applications [22,32,33]. The electrospinning technique may be considered to be a variant of the electrospraying process [34,35], both of which use a high voltage to form a liquid jet. In the past ten years, various electrospun fibers with precisely controlled fiber morphology, diameter, and arrangement have been successfully obtained through tuning of the electrospinning parameters, which has broadened the application of electrospun fibers into the biomedical field. The aim of this review is to provide the ‘state-of-the-art’ and current guidelines in preparation of different structured electrospun polymeric fibers for the purpose of biomedical applications, including drug delivery, tissue engineering and regenerative medicine, diagnostics and other applications in medicine.
2. Electrospinning process and available biomaterials
2.1. Process and parameters
A typical setup for electrospinning is composed of several basic parts: a high voltage (usually direct current (DC)) power supplier, a spinneret (usually a stainless needle with a solution container), a syringe pump, and a grounded collector (usually aluminum foil). The spinneret, which contains the spinning solution or melt, is connected to one electrode of the high voltage power supplier and the grounded collector is placed directly below the outlet of the spinneret, located at a proper distance. During electrospinning, a small droplet (a Taylor cone) hangs at the outlet of the spinneret,

Subsequently these small diameter coils were incorporated into a larger diameter bending instability coil, producing a complicated jet path, which was called a “garland” (Fig. 2b, c). The coils entangled and conglutinated in flight to form a fluffy network of fibers.
During this process, many factors would affect the jet movement and influence the final products, including the molecular structure of the polymers (molecular weight and architecture (branched or linear)), the solution properties (concentration, viscosity, surface tension and conductivity), voltage, flow rate, collecting distance, the diameter of the spinneret, and other ambient parameters (temperature, humidity, gas atmosphere, air flow and pressure, etc.) [40]. .2. Available biomaterials
Thus far, numerous polymers have been utilized for electropinning, which can be roughly divided into natural polymers, ynthetic polymers, multicomponent composite polymers and norganic/organic composite materials. Table 1 summarizes the
ost commonly reported biomaterials used in electrospinning. oly( -caprolactone) (PCL), poly(lactic acid) (PLA), poly(lactico-glycolic acid) (PLGA), poly(ethylene glycol)-co-poly(d,l-lactide) PELA), poly(ethylene glycol)-poly( -caprolactone) (PEG-PCL), PS, olyurethane (PU) are the most commonly used synthetic biopolyers soluble in organic solvents, while polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), olyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) and polyethylene oxide (PEO) are ommonly used synthetic water-soluble biopolymers. In addition, ollagen, gelatin, silk fibroin, spider silk protein, chitosan and lginate are the most commonly used natural polymers for elecrospinning. Notably, for many natural polymers which have a elatively poor solubility and a low molecular weight, electrospining into fibers is difficult without mixing in synthetic polymers. So ome synthetic polymers, such as PLA [46–48], PLGA [49,50], PCL 51], PEO [52], or PVA [53,54], are often co-electrospun with the forementioned natural polymers as carrier polymers.

electrospinning techniques are currently being developed for more precise fabrication and for finer control of a diversity of fiber morphologies, diameters and arrangements of fibers. These developments can be roughly divided into two research efforts: (1) improving the traditional electrospinning devices; (2) combining electrospinning with other polymer processing techniques.
As shown in Fig. 3 , improvements made to the traditional electrospinning devices (Fig. 3a) (e.g., a high voltage power supply, a spinneret, an injection pump and a fiber collector) were mainly focused on the spinneret and the fiber collector. In addition to the traditional single nozzle spinneret or needle, double-/multiplenozzle spinnerets [84–87], coaxial/multiaxial spinnerets [88–91], side-by-side/multichannel spinnerets [92,93], the flat spinneret [94], and even the needleless spinneret (e.g., the spiral coil spinneret [95,96], the rotary cone spinneret [97], the cylinder or disk spinneret [98,99]) have been developed to achieve electrospun fibers with a wide range of individual fiber structures (e.g., coreshell structure, triaxial structure, multichannel structure and Janus fibers) or to achieve the mass production of micro-/nanofibers, as shown in Fig. 3b and c. Along with these improvements, variable air pressure [100,101] was also introduced in order to assist in the formation of the electrospinning jets.
In regards to the fiber collector, in addition to the traditional grounded conducting plate, many other collectors have been developed, including 3-D columnar collectors, which are used to fabricate fibrous tubes [102], helical spring-shaped collector (Fig. 3d) employed to fabricate 3-D nanofibrous construct [103], parallel electrodes (the horizontal parallel conductive substrates [104] or the dual collection rings [105]) that help fabricate aligned fibers (Fig. 3e, f), and patterned collection plates (more details in section 3.2.3). Various grounded rotators, which are employed to collect aligned fibers due to the work of applied mechanical force during the fiber collecting process, have also been developed, such

. Structural diversity of electrospun fibers
.1. Structural diversity of individual electrospun fibers
The normally desirable morphology of individual electrospun olymeric fibers involves a uniform diameter, a round crossection, and a generally smooth appearance. However, to satisfy he requirements of all kinds of applications, electrospun polymeric bers with various interesting and tunable secondary structures re being fabricated more often, usually by careful tuning of the lectrospinning parameters.
.1.1. Core-shell fibers Electrospun core-shell fibers, which are quite useful in many pplications, especially in biomedical applications, have been idely studied by many researchers. Both coaxial electrospinning nd emulsion electrospinning are utilized to fabricate core-shell bers. For coaxial electrospinning, a spinneret fabricated from wo coaxial capillaries is required (Fig. 3b). These coaxial capilaries were first originated for coaxial electrospraying [116], then hey were utilized in electrospinning [117] to fabricate core-shell anofibers. During coaxial electrospinning, an outer and inner spining solution are fed into the outer and inner capillary, respectively. hen, the outer and inner solutions join together to form a coaxial aylor cone as a result of carefully tailored feeding rates, conseuently forming a coaxial fluid jet in the high voltage electrostatic eld [118]. Finally, core-shell fibers (Fig. 4a) with distinct inner and uter phases are produced due to the short confluence time and the ow diffusion coefficient of polymers after electrospinning.
Because of their structures, electrospun core-shell fibers from oaxial electrospinning can delay the release of drugs when used s drug carriers, leading to a wide range of applications in conrolled drug delivery, tissue engineering, and wound dressing

and suture [119]. Additionally, coaxial electrospinning is able to fabricate nanofibers composed of polymers that are not electrospinnable or are difficult to process using conventional methods of spinning. For example, natural silk, a suitable material for producing tough biocompatible fibers, is hard to process due to its low elasticity at low concentration and its tendency to gel at high concentration [120]. Though the addition of some electrospinnable high molecular weight polymer (e.g., PEO) or the use of caustic solvents (e.g., formic acid and hexafluoro-2-propanol) can render the silk electrospinnable, the additives or caustic solvents may compromise the properties of the intended fibers (e.g. mechanical integrity and biocompatibility) Rutledge et al. reported the use of “two-fluid” electrospinning (coaxial electrospinning) to fabricate silk/PEO core-shell fibers [118,121]. After inducing the conformation transformation of silk from the random coil and/or silk I to predominantly sheet (silk II) structure by treatment of high humidity or methanol, the silk core filament is insoluble and the PEO shell can be removed by water, resulting in a solid, crystallized silk fiber. Furthermore, fibers with special structures derived from an initial core-shell structure can also be produced by coaxial electrospinning or by a derived electrospinning technique. As an example, Li et al. [91] made hollow nanofibers (Fig. 4b) with walls made of inorganic/polymer composites or ceramics which were obtained by electrospinning two immiscible liquids through a coaxial spinneret, followed by the selective removal of the cores. Chen et al. [89] prepared core/shell ultrathin fibers with a nanowirein-microtube structure (Fig. 4c), which was fabricated using a multifluidic coaxial electrospinning approach with an extra middle layer of fluid between the core and shell fluid layers present in traditional coaxial electrospinning. Zhao et al. [122] successfully fabricated tubes with two to five channels (Fig. 4d) through a multifluidic compound-jet electrospinning technique derived from a combination of coaxial electrospinning and dual nozzle side-byside electrospinning [123,124].
In addition to coaxial electrospinning, emulsion electrospinning is an alternate method for fabricating electrospun core-shell nanofibers [125] or hollow fibers [126]. For emulsion electrospinning, the spinning solution consists of uniform emulsions, including either an oil-in-water emulsion [127] or a water-in-oil emulsion [128]. In contrast to coaxial electrospinning, emulsion electrospinning does not require a coaxial spinneret; consequently, researchers do not have to consider the coaxiality of the two capillaries in the spinneret or the feeding rate of the outer and inner fluids. However, the emulsion is not a stable electrospinning solution, and the ingredients of the emulsion must be chosen carefully, which limits the development and application of emulsion electrospinning.
3.1.2. Beaded fibers Beaded fibers are commonly discovered during electrospinning, usually considered to be “by-products” of the process. Fong et al. [77] summarized that the formation of beaded fibers (Fig. 4e) may be due to the capillary breakup of the electrospun jets as a result of surface tension, altered by the presence of electrical forces. Further researches by Shin [129] and Hohman [38] revealed that the formation of beaded fibers was attributed to the axisymmetric instabilities in the fluid jet in the presence of an external electric field. .1.3. Porous fibers Porous structures on an electrospun fiber surface or through the ntire fiber matrix, as shown in Fig. 4i, can increase the surface to olume or surface to weight ratio of fibers and broaden the range f applications for electrospun fibers [139,140].
Various organic or inorganic electrospun porous fibers have een reported in the past years. For organic electrospun porous bers, the formation of pores primarily depends on the phase sepration of the different components of the electrospinning solution, pecifically, the separation between the polymers and solvents, the eparation between the polymers and the nonsolvents or the phase eparation of different polymer components. For example, Lin et al. 141] reported a direct approach for fabricating nanoporous poly-
er fibers via electrospinning in which the resulting PS fibers with icro- and nanoporous structures both in the core and on the fiber urfaces originated via solvent composition and PS solution conentration tuning. McCann et al. [142] created highly porous fibers onsisting of various polymers by electrospinning with a liquid itrogen bath used to freeze the fibers, inducing a phase separation etween the polymer and the solvent. After removing the solvent n vacuum, highly porous fibers were obtained. Megelski et al. [143] used the phenomenon of separation etween a polymer and a nonsolvent along with a high volatilty solvent to produce polymeric fibers with a porous micro- and anostructured surface. These features could be introduced in sevral different polymeric fibers, and the pores varied from densely acked, well-formed nanopores (20 nm to 350 nm in diameter) to arger, flat pores of approximately 1 m. For some special cases,

water molecules in the air may act as the nonsolvent while electrospinning a non-water-soluble polymer. Casper et al. [144] found that when electrospinning in an atmosphere with more than 30% relative humidity, increasing the humidity caused an increase in the number, diameter, shape, and distribution of pores in the fiber surface.
To take advantage of the phase separation of different polymers, a post-processing step, including solvent extraction, thermal degradation or UV irradiation crosslinking, must be done in order to remove the sacrificial phase, forming pores in the fiber. For example, You et al. [145] fabricated PGA/PLA blend fibers and used trichloromethane to remove the PLA afterwards, so fibers with interconnected pores and a circular shape were obtained.
For inorganic electrospun porous fibers, calcination has often been applied to the electrospun organic/inorganic composite fibers in order to remove the organic phases, while the remaining inorganic materials unite to form porous structures. For example, Kokubo et al. [146] produced multi-core cable-like TiO2 nanofibers through a calcination process of composite polyvinyl acetate (PVAc)/titania nanofibers by using a hot pressing pretreatment. Additionally, Sun et al. [147] prepared bamboo-like fibers (Fig. 4j) through the following series of steps: (1) preparation of the tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS)/polyacrylonitrile (PAN) composite nanofibers by electrospinning; (2) heat treatment of the precursors at 1200 ◦C in a H2/Ar (5/95 by volume) atmosphere, leading to ultrafine SiO2 clusters which then transfer and aggregate into much larger SiO2 particles lined up uniformly in the core of the nanofibers; (3) removal of the SiO2 particles in an HF aqueous solution, obtaining the final bamboo-like nanofibers.
3.1.4. Ribbon fibers In addition to cylindrical nanofibers, electrospinning can also produce fibers with a variety of cross-sectional shapes. Koombhongse et al. [148] reported the fabrication of electrospun ribbon fibers from 10% poly (ether imide) (PEI) in hexafluoro-2-propanol, as shown in Fig. 4k. They proposed a possible formation mechanism of the ribbon fiber as follows: during electrospinning, a thin, mechanically distinct polymer skin on the liquid jet was present. Subsequently, the solvent inside the fiber matrix escaped, at which point atmospheric pressure caused the collapse of the tube formed by the skin as the solvent evaporated. Thus, the circular crosssection transformed into an ellipse and then flattened, forming a ribbon with a cross-sectional perimeter nearly the same as the perimeter of the jet. Apart from PEI, several other polymers have also been electrospun into flat ribbon fibers, including polystyrene (PS) [148,149], PVA [150], polyethylene (PE) [151], silk fibroin [152–154], Ag/LaFeO3/PVP composite [155] and others. However, applications for these flat ribbon fibers have yet to have been developed.
3.1.5. Other fibers Fibers with other interesting structures can also be produced via electrospinning. For example, PCL nanofibers with a nanohybrid shish-kebab structure (Fig. 4l) mimicking natural bone structures or collagen fibrils were reported by Chen [156] and Wang [157] separately. Kessick et al. [158] fabricated microscale polymeric helical structures (Fig. 4m) on a conductive substrate by electrospinning from a two-component solution consisting of nonconductive PEO and conductive poly (aniline sulfonic acid) (PASA). Xin et al. [159] reported an approach to produce buckled polystyrene patterns by electrospinning 25 wt% polystyrene solution at relatively low applied voltage (around 2.4 kV) and short tip-to-collector distance (2–8 cm). Holzmeister et al. [160] obtained fibers with a high frequency of short branches (Fig. 4n), referred to as “barbed nanowires”, through the electrospinning of 8–1 wt% aqueous PVA solutions. .2. Structural diversity of electrospun fiber mats
The structure and morphology of the resulting arrangements f electrospun fibers or electrospun fiber mats also demonstrate reat diversity, indicated in Fig. 5. This structural diversity is ainly dependent on the collector type, one of the most important arts of electrospinning apparatus, determining the distribution nd macro-structures of the electrospun fibers. Additionally, the ther aspects of the processing apparatus, such as the electric field trength, the presence of a magnetic field, and the ingredients of the lectrospinning solutions, can also be optimized to get the desired ber mat structure. The collected electrospun fibers or fiber mats an be roughly divided into the following groups: random fibers, ligned fibers, patterned fibers, 3-D fibrous structures, fiber yarn nd other miscellaneous structures.
.2.1. Random fibers Random fibers (Fig. 5b) were the most common collection orm of electrospun fibers. These randomly oriented fibers will be btained simply by using the traditional electrospinning collector,
grounded conductive plate, because charged polymeric jets will aturally fly along a spiral trajectory during electrospinning (Fig. 2) 30]. The charged polymeric jets consist of a series of electrically riven bending coils with an increasing radius, accompanied by solent evaporation, jet splitting and other jet instabilities, and finally olidifying into randomly oriented continuous thin fibers on the rounded plate.
.2.2. Aligned fibers In some applications, including electronics [162], ultrasensitive
ensors [163] and biomedicine [61,164,165], fibers need to be colected into well-aligned structures. To obtain aligned electrospun bers, several techniques were developed via changing the trajecory and inhibiting bending instabilities of the charged jet during lectrospinning, including improvements to the collectors which ould generate additional mechanical force fields, introduction of dditional electric fields or magnetic fields and implementation of ear-field electrospinning. Based on these techniques, electrospun bers as aligned structures within a certain region were collected. iu et al. [166] summarized some of the methods for controlling lectrospun nanofiber alignment (Fig. 5b), including using mechancal forces generated with a rotating mandrel, creating electrostatic orces with a pair of parallel metallic plates, using a metallic ring ith a metallic pin in the center or an array of metallic beads, nd generating magnetic forces with a pair of permanent magets. For parallel plates, Beachley et al. [110] contributed some mprovements (Fig. 3i). Namely, they utilized parallel, automated racks to orient and collect nanofibers from an electrospinning jet. n addition to the methods above for producing aligned electrospun bers, recent studies have highlighted the use of near-field electropinning [41,42] as a promising tool for precisely controlling the rientation of electrospun fibers. Bisht et al. [42] reported the use f a viscoelastic polymer solution and a very low voltage of 200 V n order to reduce bending instabilities and to increase control over he resulting polymer jet during near-field electrospinning. In some ituations, the aligned fibers can be turned into another structures. urrao et al. [167] produced aligned, self-crimping fibers (Fig. 5c) rom electrospun aligned poly(l-lactide-co- -caprolactone) fibers ia a post-processing method of adjusting the operating temperture above the polymer’s glass-transition temperature. 3.2.3. Nanofiber yarns Electrospun nanofiber yarns (Fig. 5e) may be regarded as special 3-D electrospun fibrous structures. The fabrication of these electrospun nanofiber yarns is primarily carried out using either a water bath grounded collector [111,112,169] or a rotating drum [170–173], and then, the as-spun nanofibers are stretched manually or wound around a rotating grounded drum. For example, Smit et al. [111] used a grounded water reservoir collector to collect electrospun fibers, then drew the resulting non-woven web of fibers across the water before collecting the resulting yarn. Teo et al. [112] improved this nanofiber yarn collecting system by adding a water vortex which helped the yarn formation and facilitated yarn collection. In this way, the fibers are automatically stretched by water flow and form continuous fiber bundles at bottom of the vortex.
3.2.4. Patterned fibers Recently, researchers have demonstrated that patterned materials or materials with ordered microstructures possessed specific functions which were useful in numerous applications such as in cell-substrate interactions. These specific micropatterns have proven to be useful in promoting favorable biological responses, including enhanced protein adsorption, cell attachment and proliferation in tissue regeneration [174–176]. Therefore, designing and controlling the microstructures and patterns of electrospun fiber mats results in more meaningful and significant applications of electrospinning to biomedical technologies and other fields [177–179]. Currently, patterned electrospun fiber mats (as shown in Fig. 5f) are primarily fabricated by using electroconductive template collectors with different kinds of designed micro-/macropatterns [180,181]. Electrical forces are considered to be key factors for determining the deposition and the arrangement of fibers during this process [181].
The localized nanofiber dissolution method reported by Jia et al. [115] represents an alternate way to fabricate electrospun fiber mesh with versatile patterns (Fig. 5g). In this method, a piezoelectric jet system is needed to print solvent droplets directly onto the nanofiber mesh via electrical charge-generated pressure, resulting in patterned electrospun fibrous mesh after the dissolution of the fiber matrix by a solvent. In order to optimize the printing conditions, two major criteria should be considered: (1) the solvent drops should be big enough to efficiently dissolve the desired area of fibers, and (2) the excessive diffusion of solvents as a result of evaporation should be minimized to maintain a high resolution, implying that the solvent must be chosen carefully.
There are also other techniques available for fabricating patterned electrospun fiber mats. For example, low voltage near-field electrospinning is a useful tool for obtaining certain patterned fibers [42], as was described in Section 2.3. Alternatively, Yan et al. [182] reported a honeycomb-patterned nanofibrous structure (Fig. 5h) with a pore diameter ranging from a micrometer to over 200 m and with depths as greater than 150 m, all of which were self-assembled from a charged electrospun polymer nanofiber in a wet state on the substrate by appropriately controlling the electrospinning conditions. This self-assembly of electrospun nanofibers are driven by the competitive actions of surface tension and electrostatic repulsion. Additionally, the “nano-fiber/nets” consisted of common electrospun nanofibers and ultrafine nano-nets, may be considered as a special fibrous pattern [183]. Ding et al. [184] reported a novel 2-D “fishnet-like” nanoweb (Fig. 4i) in a 3-D fibrous mat as a result of using poly (acrylic acid) or nylon-6. The authors hypothesized that the formation of the nanowebs was dependent on the splitting of defect films, which occurred only under certain

. Biomedical applications of electrospun polymeric fibers
Owing to the structural diversity, high surface area and djustable porosity of the electrospun fibrous systems, they can be idely used in many different fields. In particular in the biomedcal field, for example, the intrinsic properties such as structural iversity and high surface area, are advantageous for the loading nd subsequent release of different drugs in drug delivery. The djustable porosity and the ability of electrospun fibers to mimic he fibrillar nature of the extracellular matrix (ECM) allow its use s promising 2-D or 3-D scaffolds for cell support and growth in tisue engineering. In addition, the high surface area and adjustable orosity of the electrospun ultrafine fibers also provide more surace area for immobilization of functional groups in diagnostics and ther applications. So far, a great deal of effort has been devoted o achieving the successful biomedical application of electrospun bers to a wide range of devices and systems, comprehensively eviewed in this section.
.1. Drug delivery
Due to the structure of electrospun fibers, and especially as a esult of the diversity in individual fiber structures, electrospun bers possess features such as a flexibility in morphological design,
high surface-area-to-volume ratio, and a similarity to the ECM. hese characteristics make electrospun fibers advantageous [194] n drug delivery, as demonstrated by the following aspects: (1) the iversity of polymers available enables researchers to accommoate compatibility with physico-chemically distinct agents [195]; 2) a high drug loading (up to 60%) and an encapsulation efficiency up to 100%) are possible [196–198]; (3) the ability to control drug elease is inherent in the system; (4) the electrospinning process is imple and cost-effective; and (5) the extensive, in depth research egarding the theories of electrospinning and the applications of lectrospun fibers provides a solid foundation for future system evelopment, which enables the development of mature commerial products based on electrospun fibers.
.1.1. Controlled release mechanism of electrospun fibers .1.1.1. Controlled release of a single drug. Several methods can be sed to achieve a sustained release of a single drug by electropun fibers, including matching drugs with suitable polymers, using ore-shell electrospun fibers or layered electrospun fiber mats as rug carriers, or by encapsulating drug-loaded particles into elecrospun fibers.
The choice of polymer is an important factor for achieving a susained release of drugs from electrospun fibers. Fortunately, a large mount of easily available polymers can be utilized for electrospining, as mentioned in Section 2.2. Chou et al. [194] summarized the ffects of different polymers for electrospinning on the drug loading apacity and drug release time.
After successful loading, drugs need to cross the barriers creted by the fiber matrix and then diffuse further into the release
r Science 81 (2018) 80–113
medium. This is the drug diffusion path, which offers a mechanism for controlling drug release. For biodegradable polymers, the release of drugs is mainly dependent on the degradation process of the polymer fibers because the degradation of the polymer matrix results in variations in the electrospun fiber morphology, changing the drug diffusion pathway and affecting the drug release. Furthermore, drugs in the degraded regions of the fiber matrix may also dissolve directly into the release medium. For non-degradable polymers that do not swell, the drug diffusion path would not change because there is no variation in fiber morphology over time. In this situation, the conditions controlling the release of the drugs are primarily other factors such as drug solubility, drug partitioning in the polymer and the drug diffusivity in the polymer. Therefore, in general, the release of drugs from the fiber matrix may be affected by fiber morphology, hydrophilicity of the fiber matrix, degradability of fiber matrix, drug partitioning and drug diffusivity in the polymers or the drug solubility in the medium.
In early studies, researchers simply blended drugs with polymers to electrospin into drug-loaded fiber mats. For example, Kim et al. [199] successfully incorporated a hydrophilic antibiotic drug (MefoxinR, cefoxitin sodium) into a poly PLGA-based electrospun nanofiber mat to achieve a controlled release of drugs over the course of 1 h. The researchers observed no loss in structure or bioactivity, and furthermore, they determined that the addition of an amphiphilic block copolymer (PEG-b-PLA) reduced the cumulative amount of released drug during the earlier release time, prolonging the drug release period up to 1 week. Yohe et al. [200] used the compound poly (glycerol monostearate-co- -caprolactone) as a hydrophobic polymer dopant with PCL to fabricate superhydrophobic electrospun fibrous mesh, resulting in a mesh with a high apparent contact angle. The air in the porous electrospun mesh may also act as a barrier component, further controlling the drug release rate.
In addition to polymer material selection, the choices available for the loading drugs are also wide ranging and versatile. Heunis et al. [201] summarized the types of drugs that were successfully encapsulated into electrospun fibers, including antibiotics, plasmid DNA, growth factors, antimicrobial components (e.g., silver nanoparticles), proteins, bacteria and phages. However, the fact that a great variety of drugs can be chosen may bring another problem, in that the physical and chemical characteristics as well as the hydrophobicity of different drugs will affect the controlled release process. For example, Carson et al. [202] reported that the release of azidothymidine, maraviroc, raltegravir, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate was much faster than tenovir in equivalent PCL/PLGA fiber formulations, suggesting that even subtle differences in the chemical structures of drugs would affect release rates. Generally, using electrospun fibers as a drug delivery system requires a careful match between the drug and the polymer.
In addition to matching the drugs with the right materials, changing the drug diffusion pathway is another effective way to control the release of drugs. Based on this approach, electrospun fibers with different structures can be fabricated to control drug release via tuning electrospinning parameters. One technique is to employ coaxial electrospinning for the fabrication of core-shell electrospun fibers as a drug delivery system. When drugs are loaded into the core layers of these fibers, the outer shell serves as an effective barrier for preventing the penetration of water molecules and the diffusion of drugs [203]. Specifically, the thickness, composition and permeability of the outer shell impacts the release of drugs in the core region of the fibers [204]. Additionally, emulsion electrospinning were also used to prepare core-shell fibers for controlling drug release [127].
An electrospun mesh with sandwich-like layers [205,206] was also used to change the drug diffusion pathway. Falde et al. [205] fabricated a drug-loaded layered electrospun mesh (Fig. 6a) with

4.1.1.2. Controlled release of multiple drugs. The treatment of some diseases (e.g., combined chemotherapy for a malignant tumor) and the repair of some defective tissues (e.g., regeneration of bone defect) requires a staggered release of various therapeutic drugs or growth factors in order to achieve the best outcome. Therefore, multi-drug loading and the programmable release of each drug species are important goals to achieve in electrospun fibrous drug delivery systems. So far, the most effective ways to realize a controlled independent release of each agent in a fibrous system require loading different drugs in different domains in the individual fiber or within the fiber mats, creating different drug diffusion paths and resulting in different release rates. In other words, differences in the spatial distribution of drugs may achieve variations in release time or may program the release of each drug species. Specifically, several techniques may aid in achieving the goals above, including the following: embedding drugs with different hydrophobicities in the same polymeric nanofiber matrix, incorporating different drug-loaded particles into electrospun fibers, loading different drugs into the inner or outer layer of core-shell fibers, or altering the composition of different drug-loaded fibers.
Embedding drugs with different hydrophobicities in the same polymeric nanofiber matrix is a simple way to realize sequential and distinct release of drugs. For example, Li et al. [213] loaded both hydrophobic dexamethasone (DEX) and hydrophilic green tea polyphenols (GTP) into electrospun PLGA fibers. The hydrophobic DEX molecules inside the fiber matrix only released from the channels formed after the early release of the hydrophilic GTP molecules.
The method of incorporating different drug-loaded particles into electrospun fibers is an effective and relatively simple way to incorporate different drugs into the same fiber matrix (e.g., hydrophilic and hydrophobic drugs in the same fibers). For example, Dong et al. [214] described the successful encapsulation of two distinct compounds as separate domains within a single electrospun fiber, achieved by first directly synthesizing two sets of PVA nanoparticles, one set containing Texas-Red labeled BSA protein and the other set containing Alexafluor 488-labeled epidermal growth factor. These nanoparticles were embedded in a biocompatible polymer (PU or PLGA) through a single-emulsion method. Second, the mixing of these nanoparticle-containing solutions followed by electrospinning of this combination achieved separate drug domains within the fibers. .1.1.3. Stimuli-responsive release of drugs. Recently, more and ore researchers have investigated electrospun fibrous drug delivry systems based on stimuli-responsive polymers [220,221]. These bers respond to external stimulation, accompanied by correponding changes in the physical and chemical properties of the olymers. In accordance with the different types of stimulation 222], these stimuli-responsive fibers can be divided as follows: hysical stimulus-responsive electrospun fibers (e.g., temperatureesponsive fibers [223,224], magnetic field-responsive fibers 225–227], light-responsive fibers [228], electro-responsive fibers 229]), chemical stimulus-responsive electrospun fibers (e.g., H-responsive fibers [230], humidity-responsive fibers [132], as-responsive fibers [231,232], ethanol-responsive fibers [233], eduction-responsive fibers [234], glucose-responsive [235] and rotein-responsive fibers [236]) or multi stimuli-responsive bers [237–239]. Theoretically, the application of these stimuliesponsive electrospun fibers in a drug delivery system may rovide a more precisely controlled drug release, in contrast o the fibrous drug delivery systems above. For example, Kim t al. [227] fabricated dual-responsive electrospun fibers conaining both doxorubicin and magnetic nanoparticles within a ber matrix made from a temperature sensitive polymer, poly(N-
r Science 81 (2018) 80–113
isopropylacrylamide). By applying an alternating magnetic field to the fiber mats, the magnetic nanoparticles inside the fiber matrix responded and produced heat periodically, causing the polymer to swell or shrink and effectively controlling the DOX release rate (Fig. 11a–c). Li et al. [224] in our group developed a novel nanogel-in-microfiber drug delivery system (Fig. 11d and e) whose release can be switched on and off in response to a temperature change. Thermo-sensitive poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (PIPAAm) nanogels were embedded within the shell layer of the electrospun core-shell nanofibers, a material which could shrink or swell in response to a variation in the environmental temperature, resulting in the formation or disappearance of nanochannels between the nanogel and shell matrix. Thus, a variation in shell permeability was created, which served as a valve to control the release of the encapsulated drug in the core layer. From the release profiles (Fig. 11e), it can be found that for the nanogel-in-microfiber device (E2), a more obviously temperature-switched reversible release of the model drug (methyl orange (MO)) was presented, where the MO concentration increased sharply at 40 ◦C, while increased slightly at 20 ◦C in all cycles. After three cycles, the cumulative drug release of E2 approached 92.72% ± 5.19%. While for the no nanogel device (E1), a relative slow and sustained release pattern was found owing to the direct diffusion of MO from the hydrophobic PCL shell, and the cumulative drug release of E1 approached only about 40%.
4.1.2. Oral drug delivery Electrospun nanofibers were also found to be useful in the oral delivery of poorly soluble drugs, since the high surface area to volume ratio enhances the dissolution rate of the nanosized drugs embedded in the nanofibers [240]. Soluble polymers (such as PVA and gelatin) were always employed. Yu et al. [241] developed an oral, fast-dissolving drug delivery membrane (FDM) prepared from electrospun PVP ultrafine fibers loaded with IBU. They found that the fast-dissolving drug delivery membrane with different doping concentrations of the drug had almost the same wetting and disintegrating time at approximately 15 s and 8 s, respectively; and 84.9% and 58.7% of the IBU were released within the first 20 s for FDM with a drug-to-PVP ratio of 1:4 and 1:2, respectively. Li et al. [242] also used PVA as the filament-forming polymer and drug carrier to fabricate a fast-dissolving drug delivery system by electrospinning. Caffeine and riboflavin were used as the model drugs. They found that the PVA/caffeine and PVA/riboflavin nanofibrous mats had almost the same dissolution time (approximately 1.5 s) and wetting time (approximately 4.5 s). The in vitro release study showed that the drugs were released in a burst manner (the caffeine to an extent of 100% and the riboflavin to an extent of 40% within 60 s) from the PVA nanofibrous matrices. Nam et al. [243] employed PVA and Soluplus (SP)-based electrospun nanofiber mat for the delivery of Angelica gigas Nakai (AGN) extract to oral cancers. The AGN-loaded PVA/SP electrospun nanofiber (AGN/PVA/SP NF) mat possesses an average diameter of 170 ± 35 nm and an entrapment efficiency of 84.6 ± 18.6%. As compared to the AGNloaded PVA (AGN/PVA) nanofiber mat, the AGN/PVA/SP nanofiber mat presented instant wetting (within 2 s) and rapid disintegration (within 3 min) properties (Fig. 12a). Aduba Jr. et al. [244] fabricated electrospun gelatin nanofiber scaffolds for oral mucosal drug delivery. They used the photoreactive polyethylene glycol diacrylate as a cross-linker to stabilize the scaffold by forming a semi-interpenetrating network gelatin nanofiber scaffold. The mucin absorption studies suggest that these scaffolds will likely encourage mucoadhesion.

4.1.4. Implantable drug delivery systems Electrospun fibers have also been widely used in implantable drug delivery systems, especially in anticancer studies. For many of these in vitro anticancer studies and anticancer drug screening, electrospun fibers are used as carriers of anticancer drugs or nucleic acids co-cultured with cancer cells; thus, the loading drugs or nucleic acids are released into the culture medium and impact the growth of cancer cells [56,205,248,249]. Regardless of the fact that large differences exist between these experimental studies and practical cancer therapies in a clinic, the drug-loaded nanofibers are useful for drug screening, pre-evaluation of drugs or carriers before in vivo experiments or as a platform to investigate the physiological characteristics of tumor cells.
In vivo anticancer implants are actually an effective local drug delivery system. Compared with systemic administration (e.g., intravenous (i.v.) injection), antitumor implants effectively ensure the drug concentration is at a relatively high level near the tumor tissues and reduce the distribution of the drug in surrounding normal tissues, thereby reducing side effects [250–252]. Additionally, implants decrease the drug administration time, which lessens the pain felt by patients [252]. Because electrospun fibers effectively control drug release and are easy to degrade in vivo, electrospun drug-loaded fibers are a promising local drug delivery system. So far, several studies regarding electrospun drug-loaded fibers as antitumor implants have been reported [253–256]. The antitumor efficacy of the implants was evaluated mainly according to the tumor size or weight changes and the histological analysis after the treatment, while animal body weight as well as survival rate was always used to evaluate the safety of the implants. In addition to anticancer studies, electrospun fibers have also een used as implantable devices as a potential therapy for gout ttacks, anti-viral and antibiotics, as well as surgical applications. or example, Wang et al. [262] developed luteolin-loaded electropun PCL/gelatin composite fibrous mats and implanted them near he gout sites of the New Zealand rabbits’ knees. They found that hese implantable devices alleviated acute gouty arthritis and may ffer a potential gout therapy for overcoming recurrent attacks. lakney et al. [195] reviewed the application of electrospun fibers n vaginal anti-HIV drug delivery. According to their oppinions, rug-eluting fibers can be designed to achieve multiple design contraints in a single product for topical HIV prevention, because
r Science 81 (2018) 80–113
electrospun fibers are able to deliver diverse agents, incorporate multiple agents via composites, and facilitate controlled release for pericoital and sustained (coitally-independent) use, and it is technologically feasible to scale-up. However, challenges of using electrospun fibers still exist, like issues related to vehicle deployment, spreading and retention in the vaginal vault, the unknown safety and toxicity of the interaction of the fibers with the mucosal environment, and difficulties in precisely controlled release of multiple drugs from a single electrospun fiber mat.
The application of electrospun fibers in local and sustained delivery of antibacterial agents is promising for the treatment of recurrent and chronic infections, especially in cases involving antibiotic-resistant bacteria [133,263]. Song et al. [264] fabricated a PLLA electrospun fibrous membrane containing levofloxacin (Lev) and silver loaded mesoporous silica nanoplatform (Lev@MSN@Ag) via blending electrospinning for the treatment of drug-resistant bacterial infections. These Lev@MSN@Ag–PLLA electrospun fibrous membrane, with low concentrations of drugs (28 g/mL Lev and 12 g/mL Ag), shows superior antibacterial ability against drug-resistant strains (methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus, MRSA) with a concentration of 5 × 105 CFU/mL in the in vitro test. Furtherly, the in vivo study demonstrated that these fibers could significantly inhibited bacterial growth and infection over 8 weeks. Ashbaugh et al. [263] developed an electrospun composite coating comprised of PLGA nanofibers embedded in a PCL film for locally co-deliver combinatorial antibiotics (either linezolid (Lin), vancomycin (Van), daptomycin (Dap) or rifampin (Rif)) from the implant surface. The release of each antibiotic would be adjusted by loading each drug into the different polymers or by varying PLGA/PCL polymer ratios. The authors used an in vivo (mouse) model of prosthetic joint infection (PJI) to evaluate the PLGA/PCL composite-coated K-wires (an implant) against S. aureus (strain Xen36, which possesses a stable bioluminescent construct). Three different combinations of antibiotic-loaded coatings (Van/Van + Rif, Lin/Lin + Rif and Dap/Dap + Rif each) were placed in the right femoral intramedullary canal of mice and S. aureus (1 × 103 CFU) was pipetted directly onto the protruding implant in the knee joint before closure. The in vivo bioluminescence imaging was applied to noninvasively monitor the bacterial burden and CFU from the homogenized bone/joint tissue samples and from the sonicated implants were assayed on day 14. Results showed that bioluminescence imaging signals from all these three different combinations of antibiotic-loaded coatings approached background levels and had <100 CFU (Van/Van + Rif) or no CFU (Lin/Lin + Rif and Dap/Dap + Rif) in the bone/joint tissue and no CFU detected from the implants, indicating these combinations of antibiotic-loaded coatings were highly effective in preventing infection of the bone/joint tissue.
The electrospun fibers were also employed for preventing tissue adhesions, one of the most common postsurgical complications and compromised the quality of patients’ life, occurring simultaneously as the damaged tissue heals and accompanied with inflammation, pain and even dyskinesia in particular circumstances [265]. For example, Bölgen et al. [266] reported an antibiotic embedded electrospun PCL membranes for prevention of abdominal adhesions. The antibiotic (Biteral ® ) solution was dropped slowly and distributed evenly on the electrospun PCL membrane, then absorbed and embedded by the membrane. The antibiotic embedded PCL membranes were implanted on the right side of the abdominal wall on a rat model, which significantly eliminated postsurgery abdominal adhesions, and improved healing. The prevention of peritendinous adhesions by using electrospun fibers was also reported. Jiang et al. [267] incorporated Celecoxib into PELA fibrous membranes via electrospinning and found that these Celecoxib-loaded PELA membranes could down-regulate ERK1/2 and SMAD2/3 phosphorylation, leading to reduced collagen I and collagen III expression, inflammation reaction, and fibroblast and

.2. Tissue engineering and regenerative medicine
In addition to the application of electrospun fibers in drug delivry systems, these materials are also widely used as scaffolds for issue engineering due to their inherent structural features. The ontinuous thin fibers created by electrospinning have the ability to imic the ECM because of their large surface areas, complex fibrous nterfacial topological structure, ease of functionalization, and conrollable mechanical properties, and may be an ideal method for abricating tissue engineering (TE) scaffolds [270,271]. Currently, esearch in this area is devoted to cell penetration, the incorporaion of growth and differentiating factors, the toxicity of solvents sed, overall productivity, and the creation of functional gradints. Progress in the use of electrospinning for TE applications is ighlighted below. In tissue repair research, various electrospun brous scaffolds which mimic native extracellular matrices should e applied in accordance with the natural organization of cells, ncluding the use of random, aligned and 3-D structural fibers in rder to adapt to the demands of tissue repair. For example, as hown in Fig. 13a, Liu et al. [166] summarized typical examples of issues in the human body whose regeneration would benefit from he use of anisotropic structured electrospun nanofiber scaffolds. ere, we review the application of electrospun fibers in various tisue regeneration fields, including wound dressing, vascular tissue ngineering, muscle tissue engineering, neural tissue engineering, one tissue engineering and others.
.2.1. Wound dressing Skin, the largest organ of the human body, is composed of three
ayers, the epidermis, dermis and hypodermis and behaves as a barier with protective, immunologic, thermoregulatory and sensory unctions [272].
Conventional skin substitutes such as autografts, allografts and enografts have been employed for skin regeneration. Autografts re the gold standard of skin therapies because they are not subject o rejection, and yet, because of limited availability, the risk of donor ite morbidity and scar formation, safer substitutes are needed
r Science 81 (2018) 80–113 101
[273,274]. Allografts and xenogafts are more available alternatives but carry the risk of disease transmission and immunological rejection [64,273,275]. Recent attempts have focused on the development of bioengineered substitutes as a promising therapeutic alternative capable of facilitating skin regeneration and wound healing for the treatment of acute and chronic wounds or burns. Several scaffold types, such as films, sponges, micro- and nanofibers made of natural and synthetic polymers, have been developed to date [276].
The high specific surface area of nanofibers is a significant advantage as it enhances fluid absorption, dermal drug delivery and exhibits better absorption of functional proteins such as albumin, fibronectin and laminin on the surface [277]. Moreover, the high porosity of these electrospun nanofibrous scaffolds facilitates the exchanges of oxygen, water and nutrient as well as the removal of metabolic waste. Additionally, the small-sized pores restrain the penetration of harmful microorganisms [40]. Numerous studies on the application of electrospun nanofibrous scaffolds with various components for skin substitutes and wound dressings have been reported. For example, Powell et al. [278] compared freeze-dried and electrospun collagen scaffolds as skin substitutes and found that the electrospun scaffold skin substitutes possessed optimal cellular organization, potentially reducing wound contraction, as shown in Fig. 13b. Zhang et al. [279] utilized coaxial electrospinning to fabricate individually collagen-coated PCL nanofibers (i.e., Collagen-r-PCL in the form of a core-shell structure) and found that the density of human dermal fibroblasts on the core-shell nanofiber membrane increased linearly by 19.5% (2 days), 22.9% (4 days), and 31.8% (6 days) as compared to PCL nanofibers. Qu et al. [280] developed a system in which collagenase was stored inside PEO electrospun nanofibers and released upon hydration. Through a series of in vitro and in vivo studies, their findings show that the partial digestion of the wound interface improved wound repair by creating a more compliant and porous microenvironment which expedited cell migration to and/or proliferation at the wound margin. Sun et al. [281] constructed a 3-D fibrous scaffolds for accelerated vascularization by using a photocrosslinkable natural hydrogel based on gelatin methacryloyl (GelMA) via electrospinning. They found that the ultraviolet (UV) photocrosslinkable gelatin electrospun hydrogel fibrous membranes, possessing soft adjustable mechanical properties and controllable degradation properties, can support endothelial cells and dermal fibroblasts adhesion, proliferation, and migration into the scaffolds, which facilitates vascularization. After the fibrous scaffold was implanted below the skin flap in a rat model, the skin flap survival rate was higher than the control group, and more microvascular formation was observed, which was potentially beneficial for the flap tissue vascularization.
The morphology of an electrospun fiber mat also affects the growth of seeded fibroblasts. For example, the alignment of the fibers may control cell orientation and strengthen the interaction between the cell body and the fibers in the longitudinal direction [282,283]. Furthermore, Ma et al. [284] developed sandwich-type scaffolds as microskin grafts for use in skin regeneration consisting of radially aligned nanofibers as the bottom layer, nanofiber membranes with square arrayed microwells and nanostructured cues as the top layer, and microskin tissues in the middle. The microskin tissues were confined in the square arrayed wells and simultaneously guided by the nanotopographic cues, facilitating the in vitro migration of the cultured NIH 3T3 fibroblasts and primary rat skin cells. These sandwich-type transplants displayed an even distribution of those microskin grafts and improved the “take” rate of the microskin tissues, promoting re-epithelialization on the wound. Additionally, the void region in the scaffolds promoted exudate drainage from the wound. Reis et al. [285] reported a electrospun 3-D fibrous construct with an asymmetrical inner structure

4.2.2. Vascular tissue engineering Vascular tissue engineering preparation methods using electrospun fibers can be divided into a few categories: (1) as-spun micro-/nanofiber tubes used to directly culture cells, making blood vessels [106,190,288,289]; (2) flat fiber membranes seeded with endothelial cells or smooth muscle cells for a certain time, then rolled into vessels [290,291]; and (3) as-spun micro-/nanofiber tubular scaffolds implanted in vivo and used to induce cells from experimental animals to migrate into the scaffolds in order to finally obtain vascular tissue [292,293].
For the first method, in 2008, Zhang et al. [102] fabricated 3-D fibrous tubes composed of ultrafine electrospun fibers with a novel static method as shown in Fig. 4l. By using this technique, integrated macro tubes can be prepared directly. Browning et al. [289] developed a multilayer vascular graft based on collagen-mimetic proteins. They used electrospun polyurethane tubular mesh to reinforce the tubular PEG-Scl2 hydrogel during the formation of the tubular hydrogel, achieving suitable biomechanical properties. This PEG-Scl2 hydrogel, who was able to bind to endothelial cells (ECs) and resist platelet adhesion, was fabricated by conjugating a collagen-mimetic protein derived from group A Streptococcus,

.2.3. Muscle tissue engineering Human muscle tissues, including skeletal, cardiac, and smooth
uscle, not only function as a locomotive apparatus but also eliver the protein breakdown products and maintain the noral functioning of the organs [294–296]. Although the muscle
issues have an inherent capacity for regeneration following injury, evere trauma (e.g., volumetric muscle loss), tumor ablation or eart disease, may overwhelm these natural muscle repair mechnisms. Thus, muscle tissue engineering have been focused in ecent years [297–299]. ECM-like electrospun fibers are suitable or muscle cell adhesion and proliferation and the fiber align-
ent is one of the most important parameters for muscle tissue ngineering [300]. Compared to scaffolds with randomly arranged bers, scaffolds with highly aligned (anisotropic), or unidirectionlly oriented fibers have been repeatedly demonstrated to enhance yoblast adherence, proliferation, myotube formation and musle cell alignment. Additionally, the porosity of a fibrous scaffold
r Science 81 (2018) 80–113 103
and the extent of cell infiltration affects the muscle cell growth. For example, water-soluble polymers co-spun with PCL could be easily removed following scaffold fabrication, resulting in spaces that act as pathways for improving cell infiltration [301]. Along with the fiber structure (the topographic cues), sensitivity of cells to other physical stimuli can be incorporated into the nanofibers. For example, electrically conductive materials were incorporated within aligned electrospun PCL [302–304], polyurethane [305] and PCL/polyaniline (PANi) [303] scaffolds (Fig. 13d), leading to a more efficient electrical stimulation in the developing cultures and further improving myotube maturity. Mechanical stimulation and substrate stiffness are other factors that have been previously demonstrated to influence skeletal muscle development. Elastomeric polyurethane scaffolds prepared with optimal stiffness and cyclical mechanical strain during culturing led to the development of more mature, striated myotubes than with fiber alignment alone [305]. In addition, the muscle tissue engineering, especially the field of cardiac tissue engineering, has continuously moved from 2-D culture systems to 3-D culture systems which are more representative of living systems [299]. Some other techniques (such as micropatterning [297] and microfluidics [298]) have been combined with electrospinning to build novel and functional 3- D scaffolds for muscle tissue engineering. For example, Fleischer et al. [306] reported a bottom-up approach to assemble a modular tissue consisting of multiple tissue layers with distinct structures and functions. One layer was designed to support cardiac cells and promote their organization into a contracting tissue. On this layer, they created microgrooves (width of 115 ± 5 m, ridge width of 120 ± 2 m, and height of 110 ± 10 m) on the thin albumin electrospun fiber layer via laser-patterning for increasing the surface area of the fibrous scaffold and mimicking native anisotropy of the natural ECM. Microholes (40 ± 0.8 m in diameter) were also created on the ridges of the fibrous layer to increase the mass transfer between different layers. Another layer enables the organization of endothelial cells into blood vessels, which were patterned with microtunnels (450 m) to form a predefined vasculature, and cage-like structures between the microtunnels to accommodate controlled-release systems to continuously supply signals for vascularization. The PLGA microparticles enabling a long-term VEGF release were deposited into the cages, while endothelial cells were seeded onto the microtunnels. Furthermore, the third kind of layers with cage-like structures contain drug-loaded PLGA microparticles enabling the controlled release of different biofactors (e.g. DEX, an anti-inflammatory agent) affecting the engineered tissue or the host. Before transplantation, the tissue and microparticulate layers were integrated to form thick 3D cardiac patches by an ECM-based biological glue. Finally, the patches were transplanted in rats. After 2 weeks, they found that patches without the VEGF remained white, while the VEGF-loaded patches were filled with blood vessels. The histological analysis and immunostaining the extracts for smooth muscle cells, which stabilize blood vessels, further demonstrated that the ability of the VEGF microparticulate layer to improve blood vessel infiltration into the cardiac patch.
4.2.4. Neural tissue engineering The use of electrospun fibrous scaffolds as substrates for neural tissue engineering has also been investigated by many researchers [307–309]. In vitro and in vivo experiments of substrates using polymer films versus electrospun fibers determined that the electrospun fiber-based substrates had a higher efficacy in enhancing nerve regeneration. In vitro, patterns of neurite cell outgrowth from the primary dorsal root ganglia (DRG) seeded on a scaffold of electrospun nanofibers with various order, structures, and surface properties were seen. As shown in Fig. 13e, neurite outgrowth occurred radially without specific directionality on randomly oriented nanofibers, while the cells preferentially extended along the

.2.5. Bone tissue engineering In the bone reconstruction field, electrospun nanofibers have lso attracted considerable attention, which has primarily been imed at identifying suitable material compositions for electropinning [318]. Bone-associated cells and their progenitor/stem ells show initial responses similar to those in other tissues, which re often anchorage-dependent. The nanofibrous substratum may rovide favorable conditions for cell anchorage and growth. In tanem with initial cell responses, further osteoblastic differentiation nd mineralization have also reportedly been well regulated on anofibrous surfaces as compared to a dense substrate of polyers [319]. Although studies on the in vivo feasibility of electrospun anofibers in bone reconstruction and tissue engineering are in the arly stages, recent reports using electrospun nanofibers with new ompositions targeted for bone growth as well as some processng tools for designing 3-D scaffolds have highlighted the potential se of electrospun materials in bone tissue engineering. To broaden he application of electrospun nanofiber in bone tissue engineering, ur group has developed various electrospun nanofiber scaffolds o promote either in vitro or in vivo osteogenesis, including the ollowing: beaded nanofibers with surface nanoroughness for modlating and facilitating cellular behaviors [130,131], electrically onductive electrospun aligned PLA/MWCNTs nanofibers with a ynergistic combination of topographic cues and electrical stimuation for osteoblast outgrowth [61], a 3-D nano/micro alternating
ultilayered scaffold loaded with rBMSCs and BMP-2 [320], and anoparticle-embedded electrospun nanofibers for the efficient epair of critical-sized rat calvarial defects (Fig. 13f) [66].
.2.6. Other applications In addition to aforementioned applications of electrospun fibers, here are many other potential applications in tissue engineering. or example, Jiang and Li et al. [321] developed aligned PCL–PEG anofibers in porous chitosan scaffolds in order to improve the rientation of collagen fibers in regenerated periodontium. Liu t al. [322] formulated dextran glassy nanoparticles (DGNs) loaded ith basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) and encapsulated these anoparticles into poly-l-lactic acid (PLLA) copolymer fibers in rder to secure the bioactivity of bFGF in a sustained manner, hus promoting cell proliferation and tendon healing both in vitro nd in vivo (Fig. 13g). Xie et al. [164] demonstrated the fabication of “aligned-to-random” electrospun nanofiber scaffolds hat mimic the structural organization of collagen fibers at the endon-to-bone insertion site. Tendon fibroblasts cultured on such
scaffold exhibited highly organized and haphazardly oriented orphologies on the aligned and random portions, respectively. hey also prepared scaffolds based on radially aligned electrospun anofibers, which showed great potential as artificial dural substiutes (Fig. 13h) [323]. This scaffold was able to direct and enhance
r Science 81 (2018) 80–113
the cell migration from the periphery to the center and induce faster cellular migration and population than random nanofibers. The authors also found that dural fibroblast cells, which cultured on the scaffolds of radially aligned fibers, expressed extracellular matrix like type I collagen in a high degree of organization. Xue et al. successfully used electrospun gelatin/polycaprolactone fibrous membranes to build an ear-shaped cartilage (Fig. 13i) [324]. Liu et al. [325] developed electrospun fibrous scaffolds with 200 nm fiber topography enhanced retinal pigment epithelial culture (Fig. 13j), which showed subretinal biocompatibility. Jungebluth et al. [326] used electrospun polyethylene terephthalate (PET) fibrous tubular scaffold (with inner diameter of 2–3 mm and wall thickness of 0.5-1.0 mm) as a model of the artificial tracheal tissue engineering scaffold. They used a tissue engineering strategy and orthotopic transplantation of this artificial model scaffold together with the natural decellularized donor tracheae to illustrate that their protocol was a reliable and reproducible model which could be used to investigate the critical aspects and pathways of in situ tracheal tissue restoration and regeneration. Their protocol also included details about the way to assess the scaffolds’ biomechanical properties and cell viability before implantation. Wang et al. [327] fabricated a hierarchical microwell-array scaffold by using electrospun thermoplastic silicone PU nanofibers for cell-transplantation to treat diabetes. During the fabrication process, the electrospun PU nanofibers were deposited onto a conductive PDMS micropillar-array patterned collector. This scaffold effectively allowed for assembling of islets and aggregates of mensenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in high density, which enabled the transplantation of cells with spatial control and improved the transplant’s engraftment efficacy in vivo for treating diabetes. For the in vivo transplantation, a circular microwell scaffold (with diameter of 7 mm) containing 250 islets was transplanted into the streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic mice in the epididymal fat pad (EFP). The EFP is a transplantation site featured with well-perfused fat tissue and convenient accessibility through facile operation procedures. The results of nonfasting blood glucose measurements during 120 days after the transplantation, suggested that the islets-contained microwell scaffold group had well-preserved metabolic function, with no significantly difference from the normal mice group.
4.3. Diagnostics
Due to their high surface area to volume ratio, the contact area between the active sensing regions of a nanofiber mat and the cells or molecules are much higher than that of flat films. Thus, nanofiber mats have also been used to enhance paper-based diagnostics.
4.3.1. Humoral diagnosis of cancer Electrospun fibers were employed for the detection of tumor markers or circulating tumor cells (CTCs) in the blood and in other body fluids of a patient with early-stage cancer [328]. Zhang et al. [329] electrospun titanium butoxide (TBT)/PVP composite fibers onto a silicon substrate and obtained titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanofibers by a calcination process and by removing organic components. Then, they modified the nanofibers with a biotinylated anti-epithelial cell adhesion molecule (anti-EpCAM) and finally captured junction colon cancer cells and gastric cancer cells with the device. Ma et al. [330] fabricated microfibers, nanofibers and nanofibers/microbeads composite materials from PS via electrospinning (Fig. 14a), and then anti-EpCAM was used to modify the fibers. The human breast adenocarcinoma cell (MCF7) capture efficiency of these fibers was investigated, with all fibers demonstrating a relatively high capture efficiency. The nanofibers/microbeads composites possessed the highest capture efficiency. Zhao et al. [331] combined biotinylated anti-EpCAM

4.4. Other applications in medicine
4.4.1. Mimicking the tumor microenvironment A deep understanding of tumor growth and its growth environment helps improve the administration of drugs and the testing of new medicines. Therefore, various materials and methods have been used in order to mimic tumor microenvironments and to build in vitro tumor models [340–342]. With structures similar to the ECM, electrospun fibers have also been used in this type of study. Hartman et al. [343] built a 3-D growth microenvironment for tumor cells based on electrospun PCL fibers and a bioactive peptide derived from domain IV of perlecan heparan sulfate proteoglycan; this microenvironment can maintain the migration process of prostate cancer cells. Fischer et al. [344] used electrospun PCL fibers with different molecular weights and mouse fibrosis lung extract to build a 3-D microenvironment, which was then used to explore the pathogenesis of congenital pulmonary interstitial fibrosis. Considering most preclinical drug screening systems fail to predict whether a given drug candidate will work in clinical trials, which was possibly due to the fact that cells are plated on culture dishes devoid of signaling cues present in vivo, thus, San-

4.4.2. Immobilization of enzyme The high specific surface area and porosity of the electrospun fibers also help in effectively alleviating the diffusion resistance of a substrate, thus greatly improving the catalytic ability of an enzyme. Enzymes are catalysts with features of high specificity and high catalytic efficiency, which are applicable in a wide range of disciplines, including biomedicine, food engineering and other fields. However, an enzyme may not be stable in a highly acidic, alkaline or other harsh environment, and these instabilities negatively affect performance. One method for addressing these problems is to fix the enzyme onto a carrier [352]. The performance of an immobilized enzyme is highly dependent on the structure and performance of the support material, such that the selection of the carrier material is particularly important [353]. . Conclusions and future challenges
Electrospinning technology has been widely used to fabricate olymer fibers with various hierarchical structures from 1-D to 2-
to 3-D, accomplished by changing electrospinning setups and rocessing factors. The fiber matrix can be made of any number of iverse polymer materials, with the fiber diameter ranging from ano- to micro- meter and the fiber morphologies readily tunable. hese electrospun fibers have been employed for drug delivery, tisue engineering, disease diagnostics and many other applications. recise drug release and programmed drug release profiles can e achieved as a result of the well-defined multilevel structure of he fibers. The polymer fibers are ideal tissue engineering scaffolds ecause of their nanofibrous structure, which has a high surface to olume ratio and an ability to mimic the ECM of living cells. Howver, some challenges of using electrospun fibers for biomedical pplication still exist. More sophisticated electrospinning techiques need to be developed in accordance with the requirements f biomedical applications. For drug delivery (e.g., cancer therapy) pplications, joint, interdisciplinary investigations from material cientists and biologists are needed to further develop multileveled bers. The microfluidic-assisted electrospinning approach, which an more precisely control the composition of the electrospinning olution, may be a good strategy for producing those multileveled bers. For tissue engineering, a key factor is accurately controlling he fiber deposition, preferably on a nanometer scale, in order to
ore precisely mimic an ECM. Additionally, it is critical to undertand the cellular reaction to electrospun materials with different ompositions, fiber orientations and microstructures. These goals an be easier to achieve by combining the use of electrospinning, icrofluidic spinning and 3D printing to construct the 3D scaffolds onsisting of diverse fiber sizes, depositions and orientations simlar to in vivo like ECM [358]. What’ more, a database may need o be developed to record the interactions between different cells nd different fiber scaffolds for better analysis and understanding heir mutual influence and providing useful guidelines to fabricate esired scaffolds. For diagnostics, more sensitive materials should e employed during electrospinning, or surface modification of the bers by functional groups will be required [359], such as plasma reatment, polydopamine treatment and layer-by-layer technique. urthermore, the mass production of electrospun nanofibers is a ecessity for this technology to increase commercial value, which ay be hopefully realized through the needleless electrospinning 360]. Actually, the commercialization of electrospinning techique and the eletrospun fiber products was achieved in some egree [361]. In 1980s, Donaldson Co., Inc was the first to com-
ercialize electrospun fiber technology in the in the US, followed
y DuPont (micro-denier fibers). In 1991, companies from the nonovens sector within the fiber technology industry were the first to roduce commercialized filtration products based on electrospin-
r Science 81 (2018) 80–113 107
ning. Now, the air and water filtration products are still the main focus of business and industrial attentions, compared with other electrospun fibers-based products (such as protective clothing, armor, composite reinforcement, photovoltaic and energy storage devices). While the commercialization of biomedical applications of electrospun fibers (e.g., engineered skin and tissue anti-adhesion membrane) is also gathering interests. However, before the extensive commercialization of these electrospun fibers in biomedical fields, more extensive in vivo studies, even clinical trials are still needed to be done to evaluate the real influence of electrospun nano-/microfibers in healthcare and biomedical engineering. In conclusion, hierarchically structured polymer fibers have great potential for use in biomedical applications, and it is believed that they will be used in the human body with further refinements to electrospinning technology.

metadata.abstractText: Hierarchically structured polymer fibers encompassing 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D structures with at least one dimension nanoto micro-meters in size have recently received an increasing amount of attention due to their vast potential in such applications as sensing, medicine, energy storage. This review summarizes advancements in the last ten years in the design and fabrication of hierarchically structured polymer fibers via electrospinning technologies, including a diversity of electrospinning devices and electrospinning parameters using various polymers.
